Gang wars+the Supernatural+Chat Rooms=Durarara!! 
It sounds like a clusterfuck, and at times it is. But it's an enjoyable clusterfuck. In episode one we're introduced to our main characters Makato and Masaomi, through them we're given a brief introduction of the living breathing world of Ikebukuro. I said earlier that Makado and Masaomi are the main characters but that's not one hundred percent accurate. This show has more of a rotating cast, as the series goes on you'll come to know a wide group of characters and their inner circles. You'll learn about the mysterious "Headless Rider" and the back alley doctor that they live with,you'll about a shy girl that befriends Makado and Masaomi, you'll learn about a small group of friends who are involved in a color(less) gang called the "Dollars", you'll learn about a man with unnatural strength and endurance, and you'll learn about an information broker who plays puppet master to all the other characters in the series. 


This is both the shows best and worst aspect. The cast of characters is large and each of them are interesting enough but since there are so many characters and the show tries to give each of them equal screen time like it's determined to not have any characters be anything less than a main character the show as a whole suffers. There's only so much you can do when there are five different groups running around Ikebukuro doing things that are only tangentially related to each other are fighting for screen time it's kind of hard to let your characters or story grow. It's not that the creators handle this poorly...but it's a herculean task and the writers just miss the mark. But on the flipside these characters are fun to watch and I thought their personalities were enough to carry the slightly lackluster story.


The animation was great, but I'm usually not very critical of visuals so as long as there isn't too much re-used footage. Similarly I thought the sound design was fine but I'm usually not too critical of it anyway.


Overall it's a decent series that sacrifices story for a larger cast.

I had passed by Durarara!! on the title screen of Netflix countless times before actually watching it. I'm still not sure what actually drew me into starting it, but I'm sure glad I did. One particular thing that always stood out to me was the background on the info. You know, that photo that shows in the title area. The one with Shizuo, Izaya, Anri, and Mikado all lined up in suits. I can definitely remember looking at Izaya and just sensing something about him. 
Story (9/10) 
The story itself was really interesting to me. Before Durarara, I hadn't watched or explored many anime/manga genres,so it was a new intro to me. For one, I had never heard of a dullahan-type character like Celty. I would've given a ten for this section, but some parts were a bit predictable, so I deducted a point. Actually, it was going to be more like minus 3 points, but the whole color gangs and tension between the Raira gang just kinda caught me way off guard, man.


Art (9/10) 

The art compliments everything else perfectly, especially the way it's so diverse. For example, Mikado's eyes are large and give off a youthful look, which personify his naive self. On the other hand, Izaya's eyes are much thinner, and send an almost evil message. There's also little details that just make it all the more enjoyable, like when someone laughs or smirks, you can see the eyes slant the slightest, but still enough. However, just like x2's animation, there's the awful background chara's design. A prime example is in episode 25, during Shizuo and Izaya's fight.


Sound (10/10) 

The soundtrack is amazing. Really. It does an amazing job of drawing you in at all the right moments. Before discovering the soundtrack, I had been falling asleep to random music in my library. Now, I listen to a selection of the songs from it, especially the soft ones.


Character (9/10)

As I typed the word "Character," I could feel my heart slowly picking up speed, and my face was plastered with the widest grin. The characters are like, one of my favorite aspects of Durarara. Take Mikado. When he's introduced, he's shown as a shy naive boy. But as the show progresses, so does his character development. The same goes for Kida and Anri. But, the character that really stands out to me is (yes, I know he's way popular, I just love him to death) Izaya. I also love the way he was introduced in that dark alley. In the first episode, he appears all dark and mysterious (I won't say for the second episode cos I laughed when he walked out looking drunk or something lmaoo). Actually, I feel like Izaya is one of the reasons episode 3 is so iconic to me. Shizuo also plays a part there, props to him for shutting Izaya up. Speaking of those two, I might get a few confused looks here, but I always felt like Shizuo and Izaya never got to actually fight that much on screen. I mean, all they did was just talk shit about each other to others, spare episodes 3, 16 (if you count that), and 25. I think they deserved a lot more character development than what was given.


Enjoyment (9/10)

This kinda ties in with the end of the character section, but like I was saying, I think a ton of the characters never really got te chance to show their true colors. Setting that aside, I still enjoyed every second of this show. Okay, well, not the end, but you get my point. I recently finished this show for the 3rd time, and I plan to rewatch it soon. There's a reason Durarara!! became my favorite show, and it's because I loved how surreal it felt. Unlike some anime, Durarara!!'s story has good action and adventure, but it also has those scenes that just make you want to jump right in and join the conversation or whatever. (Not to say this is the only anime like that, I'm just saying the story isn't so out there and unrealistic that the calamity blends in perfectly.)


Overall (10/10)

Durarara!! is a show that'll leave you on the edge of your seat, bawling your eyes out, and laughing along with the characters, and possibly, all in one night. One of the things that make me love Durarara!! so much is that they don't kill anyone off. So you don't have to worry about that here! Just enjoy the fun times, and if you're into that kinda stuff, check out the ships. I know shizaya's super popular, but I personally believe there's a good reason for that. Also! If you enjoy the anime, you should def check out the novel! Not only do you get Yasuda-sensei's beautiful artwork, you get tons of left out details!

Durarara!! is show of many mixed emotions, for the viewer and I think for everyone involved in creating it. While overall it’s plenty entertaining and has something to say, I don’t think it fully knows how to say it, or at least say it well. It’s a savant child of storytelling but one who is misguided and confused.  It runs about on a mission, babbles excitedly to a lot of different people, brings a lot of diversity to its cast, but sometimes is overly ambitious in what it wants to say. There’s an overall story to be told here, and you get from pointA to point B in 24 episodes without emerging too confused. But the ending leaves a lot to be desired, leaving all the chaff characters and odd mysteries as more arbitrary than open-ended prospects to be revisited in its following seasons.


However, the show isn’t without some brilliance. While it’s cheaply told to the viewer rather than shown expressed through its ensemble casts’ motivations, it’s a show that moves the plot forward in a way that few shows don’t; through theme. It sets up an outsider’s underdog theme and navigates about an urban sprawl of occasionally fantastic elements, guiding the viewer to think about how complex and unknowable life, people, and their motivations are,  and it shows strongly throughout. Which when the show wants to shine through with a message, it’s so bright you can’t help but clap. The way of doing it is flawed; it gives you an ambitiously giant cast defined by their backgrounds in order to tell a story about an important few. The point of the show gets muddled and boring sometimes when everyone is talking at you. It sometimes gets boring and arbitrary having Izaya tell you about philosophy only for fighting to occur and sorta resolve some problems. This is the biggest problem with the show is that it wants to be cool and slick while remaining thoughtful and even existential. The result is messy, and the scale tips very far in one direction or too far in the other. But that it tips in either way at all gives it a high bar of a good watch from me, even if it tries to bite off more than it can chew. Above all else Durarara’s strong suit is keeping you interested and thinking along the road to a resolution even if the end result isn’t as interesting or fun as 

what brought you there. 


The art of the show is pretty run of the mill, yet its functionality is important to the storytelling to a degree. It sticks out enough to make you pay attention to what it’s about to say even if the art direction used to create distance from the characters doesn’t tell you much other than that; they’re distant from the unknown. But it’s still consistent and what I expected from an average animation standpoint. The show and its characters remain in constant motion yet there’s a different shot from each scene. It’s a simple compliment to the overall project but you’d be surprised how many shows cut corners with reused animation. The quality control of the animation is good, even if it took no risks to bedazzle the audience and become more than just average. The only hiccups that bothered me were in fight scenes that involved mobs. Combatants behind the focal characters just stared blankly or blended into crowds or backgrounds. I gripe about this because a lot of the fight scenes were the peak of interesting animation had to offer in the show.


But mobs also become important to the show’s storytelling, and shading the masses as grey forms unknown to the main characters was interesting even if it wasn’t used to its full potential. The beginning of the show sets up pretty plainly that Mikado is vulnerable and distant from everyone in his new life. Setting him apart from crowds and the unknown populace without color and highlighting those of danger a la Sin City makes full use of storytelling through a visual medium. Beyond that, I looked through promotional posters before viewing the show and thought about colors and patterns of thought afterwards. I picked up that the show had some theme patterns added purposefully to speak to the viewer. And let me say there’s a lot of yellow; caution tape in front of the characters, capped on top of characters dangerous, interesting or pivotal. It always stuck out from the rest of the color palate of grey urban cityscapes dimly lit by neon. Granted it stops being a useful color when Celty and the Yellow Scarves both have it for seemingly no reason, but it’s an important stripe that sticks out from everything else to get you to pay attention. Even when it doesn’t do much for the storytelling.


 I can’t really comment on the plot because it just isn’t there. But the micro stories contained within the overall arc can be interesting, at least in the first 13 episodes, the show kinda drops off in the second half. In addition to smaller stories being interesting the art of the show makes up for what the plot lacks to get the viewer to pay attention.  But overall the story deals with interesting ideas that make the plot that is there really compelling. At the beginning of the show the viewer is as vulnerable and uninformed of the new setting as Mikado. Like us with the show, seeing all the characters and possibly the fanbase talking about why it’s so good, Mikado is intimidated by the challenge of fitting in and being. As we keep going we find that many more characters look to blend in or make an impact on something or someone. It’s a really human theme that keeps the characters somewhat close despite their back stories that often leave a lot to be desired. However it’s always an endearing feature of the show that keeps the plot interesting even if it gets a little thin by the end. The plot isn’t interesting during its chug forward in the latter half, and it mostly about Mikado and his friends daily encounters with gangs and other characters. 


What is cool though is how show plays on the curiosity of the unknowable by introducing supernatural/magical realist characters like Celty, Shizuo and the mysterious Slasher. Their powers are more than an excuse to animate fight scenes as their supernatural abilities reveal how far other characters like Izaya and Seiji are willing to go in their quests to get what they want. Subplots revolving around as Celty’s missing head, Shizuo not being able to control his power, and the viral power of the Dollars’ network and the gossip revolving around the Slasher were the most interesting parts of the show. To me they showed everything interesting behind the yellow caution tape. They say a lot about how far out of hand exploring the unknown goes. But unfortunately that’s a very small portion of the show. From the breaks in the action or the rising tension of a scene there may be a long thought about life or existence from a character (usually Izaya). 


The thoughts and ideas are laid out almost bluntly to give the viewer to think about. They are thoughtful, but such soliloquies are so jarring and displaced from what’s going on in each slice of life episode that it seems cheap and rushed to add their message. While each discussion makes the viewer think on some level and continues thinking about the difficulties of fitting in, the shift of focus from story to plainly drawn out message cheapens the journey the viewer has taken to get to a point of reward. When the show wants to shine with getting a message across or tell an interesting microcosmic back story, it does it really well. Yet the plot slips through its hands that are too greased up with the cool factor that the show wants to have.


The characters were the weakest part of the show. I definitely liked all of them but it was really difficult to care about them. While it might seem a little harsh any characters I don’t talk about here I didn’t find interesting enough to mention. They all definitely had a cool access point that got me interested, whether they were a morally ambivalent scientist into the supernatural for the money or the starter of a mad love affair equally infected by the same human curiosity. But if the interest of the characters could be measured by a hundred meter dash Seiji and Namie would start of strong but get exhausted pretty quick. Some characters are utterly pointless other than being segues or tools for status or edging the plot forward. Tom is this to Shizuo and police biker is this to Celty. The only three characters that have much of an arc are the main three kids and what they do to cope with their pasts. I liked what pushed Masaomi and Anri to become what they did about halfway through the show, but there’s no back story for Mikado that sets him apart as a protagonist, let alone a compelling one, other than him being him being tossed in the world with us as an access point to Ikebukuro. 


Next are Shinra and Izaya, who are different and grounded in their personalities. While I wanted an in depth look at their relationship with Ikebukoro they remained strong characters because of who they love. For Shinra its an undying commitment to Celty and for it Izaya it’s his love for, well, violence and the emotional and existential pain of others. They’re supporting characters and they definitely know it, and because of it Shinra remains kind and endearingly oblivious and Izaya cheeky and morally ambivalent. And finally theres the true leaders of the pack remain Shizuo, and Celty. Their backstories are clear, motives compelling, and objectives simple. They’re also solved to a degree and they truly left me thirsting for more, and honestly are the main two reasons I’ll be getting around to season 2 at all.


Durarara is more of an exercise in interesting ideas that is held back by its own weight of everything it brings to the table. The beginning of the show builds a world of uncertainty and anxiety, filled with denizens as diverse and confused as the last. The borderline magical realism that the supernaturally gifted characters bring to the show whips up a compelling story even if its built on in a disorganized way. It’s great as a visual medium, as the distance created from the outsider theme between characters make the first half of the show amazing. Yet Durarara’s grip goes so far that it can’t really fit in the black and yellow running shoes it’s made to bedazzle its audience. Teeters between a 7 and an 8, but I'm willing to give future installments a watch.

This anime is hard to describe to anyone.First of all, people laugh at the name and assume it's some kind of a silly anime.Secondly,how the hell should I explain the plot?
This anime has a high number of characters and everyone is given almost equal amount of screentime. There is no main character. The stories of all these characters appear utterly disjointed at first, but that is not the case, as you will discover in later episodes.
The standout feature of this anime is the way it draws the viewer into the story. I felt as if I myself was walking on the streets of Ikebukuro, fightinggangs and witnessing strange paranormal incidents.\n\n
I would highly recommend this anime to anyone .

I'll keep this ( relatively) short-
Durarara!! is incredibly good, the story allows for keen insight into all of the characters and how it weaves their lives together is extremely fascinating, it mixes the supernatural with realism to create an interesting blend of post- modernism and pseudo-Gothic. (NOTE:I use the term realism loosely here)
The art is good nothing spectacular but is by no means lacking.
The opening and endings throughout the entirety of Durarara!! are all very good and overall audio is fine.
The characters are all intensely intriguing and are what truly make this story, from the transgressive high school children to the wise gangsters, their intertwinedlives create an incredibly entertaining narrative.\n\n
I love Durarara!! as it challenges the ideals of much of its audience.  While many watch anime and aspire to an abnormal life, Durarara!! challenges this notion and points out the flaws in such an ideology  and states that an abnormal life is mostly a pipe dream.\n\n
The message to take from it is 'enjoy your normal average everyday life' because the abnormal is not only unattainable but also dangerous\n

Pros:
+Best directing I've seen in an anime
+really good art design brought out even more by the directing style
+Izaya Orihara (just simply awesome in the way he speak and the way he manipulates others) & Shizuo Heiwajima (a funny character you end up routing for)
+Every main character gets their own episode for character development
+All characters are connected in some way due to a nicely written story that weaves many aspects and characters together 
+the use of supernatural elements
+voice acting is great
+Is simply just fun to watch and every episode is guaranteed a laugh or two
Cons:
-The end wasn't quite as good as the buildup to it
-Some charactershave questionable motivations (like the sister)\n
-Anri as a character is just kinda 'meh' with her back story being the weakest of the main characters (being fairly predictable and stereotypical) \n\n
Final Score: 9

I watched this anime due to someone else's recommendation. To be honest, I was really bored 'at the beginning'. It's like I was watching something aimlessly, with no expectations or anything. But a lot of things caught my attention and made the whole thing enjoyable and SUPER interesting. Hmm.. maybe I shouldn't have typed super, since it contradicts my previous statement that I found it boring at the beginning. 
Story: 
Well, the plot was awesome. It's kind of complex and unexpected. Characters met other characters unknowingly or by pure coincidence or through someone else's scheme.
However, as I said before, it's kind of boring in thebeginning. The story was kind of hard to follow, but everything connects so the ones watching might as well pay attention to the important parts of every episode. 


When I reached this certain episode, I was filled with excitement as though all those feelings of boredom never existed. From there on, things got more interesting and unpredictable, which adds up to thrill and excitement.


Characters:

I like the characters. Their personality. Their way of living. I like how it was a mixed with normal, abnormal and otherworldly: color gangs, information broker, stalker, headless rider, high school student etc.


But what really excite me was the dual-life lead by certain characters...


Overall:

I really liked it. In some of my statements, you couldn't really tell whether I liked it or not, but I really do like it. It was awesome.


I'd like to say that you should also watch the second season, but I recommend watching it after it's 3rd part is also done. It is best to watch it straight than having to wait for another episode, cause it's gonna take the excitement away.

So when I started out watching Durarara, I wasn't really impressed with what I was watching. I mean I was literally introduced to a plain ordinary boy, otherwise known as Mikado, getting off a train to this city called Ikebukuro that apparently was supposed to be interesting. While I'm not trying to necessarily hate on this anime, there were definitely times where I wasn't motivated to even watch it. Boy, was I wrong. I'll tell you why as I go down the list here:
Story:
So like I said earlier, the anime just begins to introduce you to all these characters. Mikado being one of the maincharacters and Kida, his best friend.I'll try not to reveal most of what goes on in the story. Basically, Mikado is exposed to many urban legends that surround the city such as the headless rider and the slasher. It may be just me, but when I was first learning about all these different situations that was going on, I was really confused and didn't even know what was going on. But hey, that's a mystery for you. In my opinion, this anime could've had a better "hook" persay because again, I never had that tingly feeling that would make me all excited to watch the next episode. There were however moments that would make me say "Wait, are you serious??!" or "No way!". Basically, I was shocked and surprised a lot at the development of the plot line. But at some parts where it was supposed to be a secret, I was able to easily predict who was who and what was what, but trust me, that only happened at most two times. Throughout the anime, more information about the mystery was disclosed and it all just started connecting together and actually made sense. Along the way, there were plot twists, the true identities of characters were revealed and so forth. Also, just for a fun fact and extra detail; though it wasn't listed as a genre, I would put romance as one because it was definitely noticeable. It may not be the most important factor to this plot, but it deserves to be noticed. It was very cute, but I can't tell who it's between. Sorry!~^^  


Art:

This anime revolved around the theme of gangs and beating each other up and all that good stuff. The art did fit the theme and story well. I really liked the design of Ikebukuro. It really made me feel like I was in this average city, but you know, with gang members everywhere. I can't really describe it all that well, but if I were to imagine myself in that city without knowing the anime at all, I would be able to tell that there's more to that place than meets the eye. 


Sound:

The sound was awesome in my opinion. Each OST(Original Sound Track) that played in the background of each particular scene just fitted so perfectly. Especially in certain creepy parts where it sounded like I was in some horror movie. It really did give me goosebumps. Or those moments where its just another typical day in that city, or maybe you're at that Russian sushi shop (which is what you'll see if you decide to watch it) As far as I know, it was Jazz music and it really set the mood just the way the anime intended. Moving on to the first opening and ending. Now usually, I would skip the opening, but this one just clicked with me. It was definitely catchy and had this certain beat to it that made me grab my imaginary drumsticks and tap along to it. Also, the use of electric guitar was amazing. Overall, the opening pretty much made me want to rock out with my air guitar. It sure did fit the whole gang theme well. Now the first ending...wow, that song reminds me of some Jpop song made by a boy band. The beginning was misleading cause it sounded like a rap song, but NOPE! It broke out into cute boys singing xD The second opening of this anime is average. It gave off this sad tone as if everybody made mistakes and is pondering about them. It reminded me of a lot of other songs such as the opening of Ao No Exorcist, but that doesn't mean its bad. The ending I would say is great too. The voices sounded like they came from a lot of other romance action anime. 


Character: 

As pointed out earlier in this review, one of the main characters Mikado is very ordinary, but very awkward, in a good (and adorable) way. However, his personality does bring some sort of balance compared to all the others wackos in this anime xD Kida I feel is a very complicated guy. He seems very cheery, happy, perverted, and just plain weird. But that's just what I love about him. However, like most characters in this anime, there's a dark past behind that mask of his. Anri, the girl with the glasses and famously big breasts (lol) reminds me of Mikado, except she's pretty much emotionless. I mean she smiles here and there, but in the beginning, she didn't really do or say much. Didn't give off an interesting impression unlike Kida. But as the anime changed, so did her personality. The rest of the characters all contributed to the story in some way. They were all important to the plot of course, but Im not going to talk about them. I will however discuss Izaya and Shizuo. Now Shizuo is pretty much the comic relief. Every time he beats someone up, it's just freakin hilarious to see him rip off some street sign or vending machine and throw it all over the place. The relationship he has with Izaya is obvious. They are rivals. (But I bet they secretly love each other Shizuo x Izaya for the win! lol ) Izaya reminds me of a black cat for some reason. Just a guy who you don't wanna mess with and is also very cunning. His personality is questionable due to the fact he refers to people as his "playthings" and for some "odd" reason, he always purposely goes to bother Shizuo even though he says he's a pain. (hmm, I wonder why he would do that *hint* *hint* *wink* *wink* 


Enjoyment:

So I gave this a seven for reasons that have already been stated. I mean I started the anime in July and officially finished it the year after in March. I usually don't do that. So I really must've not been interested enough to even keep watching it til the end. But I realized that I needed to be more patient with it. and what do you know, that old phrase "good things come to those who wait" is true. I was given a great ending and ova. I felt they could've taken their time with ending Durarara, but oh well, it was good enough. There was closure to everything...well...eh...mostly everything. I can't say what I wished was elaborated more on. However, that's only one issue. The rest were answered, although kind of rushed, but still a good answer. When I finished the anime, I had a thought that went along the lines of "Wow, that was one great anime. So glad I decided to finish it" 


Overall:

I've already said what I thought of this anime. To those who are hesitant about watching the anime. My advice to you is to be patient. It may seem boring at first, but when the moment when everything given is just put together is just so worth the wait. Definitely a mystery worth watching!~ :D

"It all happened here at Ikebukuro."
This is a street gang soap opera of a series. It is driven by some of the most ridiculously zany characters I have seen. From the first episode it is easy to see why it's a popular anime series. There's everything from headless horsewomen to black Russian sushi greeters. This is a must see.
The story is told in a very busy way. It's non-linear with a lot of backpedaling and intersecting between the various character story lines. It is brilliant at times, but the chaotic delivery does get distracting at some parts. This series started to lose me a bituntil the 10th episode where the first major twist came into play. From that point forward I was watching very intently.


The artwork was done very nice. Background characters were dull and gray in color so as not to distract from the extremely colorful characters that were important for each scene. It made them stand out that much more, and it was used as a great delivery tool at certain key moments. 


The music fit the craziness of the story. It complimented the voice acting, though the narrative done by each character was a bit busy at times. Overall I have no complaints about the quality of the sound.


This series really boiled down to it's characters. Each character was funny in one way or another. Some were disturbingly funny in how twisted they were in the most bizarre of moments, while others were very slapstick. The humor in the story was sometimes out of left field in such a refreshing way. This did not steal any of the dramatic scenes, as there were still plenty of emotional moments as well. Each character had a background story that unfolded in a very interesting way. It's hard to talk about the characters, because I am tempted to fill this review with spoilers. Let just say characters make this world go round.


There are plenty of surprises, plenty of twists, and there's lots of enjoyment to be had in this series. I do want to reiterate what I said before about it losing me a little in the beginning. I had tried to watch this series a few months ago but put it down after the sixth episode. This time around I almost did the same thing due to the chaotic delivery, but then episode 10 ended and I couldn't stop watching.


If you enjoy zany character driven stories, then this is for you. Definitely check this one out.

Warning: I might end up being kind of bias because I really love this anime. I'm not sure if this clogs my judgment but I thought you should know.
Last summer I had a lot of free time on my hands and I wanted to take that free time and waste it. So I began watching a lot of weekly animes. One of these was Durarara!! which became one of my favorite animes almost instantly.
Durarara!! is about the Tokyo district Ikebukuro and all the strange happenings that occur there. The main character, Mikado Ryuugamine (who spelled that right? I SPELLED THAT RIGHT!), has just moved tothe area right outside of Ikebukuro and is now attending school there with his best friend Masaomi. These two and their new friend Anri are pulled into the midst of a dangerous game in which only one person, the creepy and possibly insane Izaya Orihara, knows all the players. Some of the interesting entities in this show include a gang whose members are completely unknown, a man with super strength and a bad temper, and a headless motorcyclist who is searching for her long lost head.


So that is the simplest version of this plot which jumps from perspective and to perspective like a rabbit on caffeine. Mikado may be the main character but he is one of the people you know least about because the plot focuses on all characters in near equal amounts.


The animation in this series is wonderful. It's by the same studio who did Baccano and, just like Baccano, it has a very earthy texture and subdued colors. The movement is clean and realistic and the character design is subtle yet distinctive (as in, they all look different, but very few look ridiculous).


The one thing about this series I admire most, however, is it's uninhibited approach to fantasy. Realistically, if strange stuff happened on a regular basis it would eventually become normal and that's how Durarara!! is approached. Even though one of the characters has NO HEAD (I can't stress this enough) the series is never treated like fantasy and the other characters don't treat her strangely either. And even though another character throws vending machines, it's never suggest that this is unrealistic.


And it's not like the characters live in a different reality. This is OUR reality and these people where made to be like normal people. Even though, by our standards they're not.


The main character actually spoke about this at one point. I can't remember the exact quote but it went something like "I always wanted to lead an extraordinary life. I didn't know, however, that something that is unusual is only unusual for a few days and then it becomes normal. I can't live an extraordinary life because, to me, my life will always be 'ordinary'."


So that's Durarara!!. An ordinary tale about extraordinary happenings.

I have to say was not sure what to expect from this anime, whether is was going to be a romance, a comedy, or even some action thrown in there. I'm proud to say though that it had all these elements and more and that's why i liked it so much. 
Having all these elements in Durarara are what make it so great, you have the relationships in it that you want to see through to the end, bits of fighting scenes that shock you and may even make you laugh, and then learning about certain characters and what makes them tick. This aspect isone i loved, you seem to learn more and more about each character in Durarara as it progresses. Its also unique in how the narrator changes each time to give you a new feel for each episode. I just don't want to say too much in the hopes you check it out for yourself.\n\n
So that being said, this was a very good anime and is worth being checked out.

**THIS REVIEW MAY CONTAIN A FEW SPOILERS**
After hearing a large amount of praise for this anime and as well as the sizable fanbase that it has gathered over 5 years I finally decided to watch Durarara!! and I found Durarara!! to be an very interesting anime due to just how insane it is with it's story and how it handled characters.
Story: (7/10)
The story of Durarara!! begins with a guy named Ryuugamine Mikado who has always wanted to visit Tokyo because he has never gone outside his town before finally gets his wish and starts living in Ikebukuro. After seeing the urban legend called the BlackRider on the first day in the city, many weird events begin to occur all around Ikebukuro. The story for Durarara!! is definitely a unique one because of how the story doesn't just go from point A and B like most anime do, each character has a separate story that is told through their perspective that all eventually intertwine together and seeing all the stories come together is very satisfying. Another thing Durarara does with its story is that it tends to change how the story is told by sometimes suddenly transitioning to past events which is an interesting method of storytelling but can sometimes lead to confusion because of how we are not told that the events actually took place in the past until it finally leads up to current events that are happening and then being able to realize that it was a past event, so I would say that this is a negative for the story due to the confusion that it causes. Another problem I found in the story was how in the end of the anime it left some loose ends which made it a somewhat unsatisfying ending but since there are 3 more seasons after this I think that those should be able to fix this.


Art and Animation: (6/10)  


I thought that the art for Durarara!! was fine because it would sometimes look unappealing due to how the people in the background would be not colored in and would be left white or purple. I thought that the backgrounds could also use a bit of work. There were many good character designs. The animation even thought that it would look choppy at times was actually pretty good.


Sound: (7/10)


The soundtrack in Durarara!! I would say is pretty good because of how all the music is varied and how it could help build an atmosphere during scenes. The OPs and EDs are good. The voice acting was above average and the sound effects are average.


Characters: (7/10)


The characters are definitely the best part of Durarara!! and that would make sense since Durarara!! is a character driven story. Most of the characters are well written with the backstories that they are given and I found Izaya to be the best one out of all of them because of his personality and how he would just observe events unfold before him like it was all a part of his plan. My only problem with the characters would be how some characters would have more development than others and even Mikado didn't much screen time compared to the other characters but that would probably be due to the large amount of characters that are in this anime. 


Enjoyment: (7/10)


I definitely enjoyed this anime and I will plan to watch the second season next.


Overall: (7/10)


If you want an anime that has a unique and entertaining story with a cast of  dynamic characters I would definitely recommend this anime to you.

Well, you can say after the debut of Baccano! In Japan and possibly the states, you could say you hope to find more anime that’s similar to this with its’ large cast of enteraining characters and their larger-than-life wild and serial antics but luckily, this series is also adapted by a light novel from the same author Ryohgo Narita and is also made by the same animation company Brains’ Base.
Ryūgamine Mikado is a boy who longs for the exciting life of the big city. At the invitation of his childhood friend Masaomi, he transfers to a school in Ikebukuro. Masaomi has warned him about peoplehe doesn't want to cross in the city: a champion fighter, an informant, and a mysterious gang called "Dollars." Nervous from Masaomi's stories, Mikado witnesses an urban legend on his first day in the city, the Headless Rider astride a black motorcycle. From then on, the existence of supernatural cases and a gang called the Yellow Scarves will rise to the surface, and Ikebukuro will pushed to the breaking point.


Like in Baccano!, this show has a very large cast of characters and the majority of them are very entertaining to watch and you would want to watch them over and over and over again. For example, Celty Sturluson aka The Black (or Headless) Rider, who came to Japan to search for her stolen head and the only way of her communicating via PDA, which to me, is a small shame, considering when the audience hears her voice, it’s actually quite pleasant. Throughout the series, she lives with underground doctor Shinra Kishitani and eventually both of them pursue a romantic relationship with each other, which to me, is something I find to be sweet and weird at the same time…..I mean, think about it. I don’t think many people would want a girlfriend with no head….actually, no. ALL PEOPLE don’t want a girlfriend without a head! Despite that, I find their plotline and relationship interesting and fascinating. Next up, it’s Shizuo Heiwajima, a blond man in a bartender’s suit who hates to be angered and loathes violence but when his fuse gets shorter and when he fights, he has the strength of 100 bodybuilders and when these moments happen, you feel so into these character, much like Ladd Russo in Baccano!, only this guy isn’t a crazy killer, just pretty damn crazy.


Then it’s the four supporting characters that you wish you want to meet in real life: Kyohei Kadota, Walker Yumasaki, Erika Karisawa, and Saburo Togusa. Kyohei is the leader of their group, especially after all four quitting the Blue Squares, and really hates to be called Dotachin. Walker and Erika are passionate otaku and manga reader, which I get many of them, will know the references. There was a few times that Walker may seem dumb due to that smile in his face but sometimes putting a dumb look can help hide your true intentions (if you hide it right). Erika likes a lot of yaoi/fujoshi and is a Boys Love fan. It is also implied that they are romantically linked and there’s Saburo, who is the driver of the group and gets mad whenever his van is wrecked.  I just really like the dynamic of this group, like they are actual friends; they think together as a group and would stick together through some tough events.


Of course, there is Simon Brezhnev, a tall Black Russian man who runs a sushi shop and while he is a force to be reckoned with, he’s more friendly and uses his mind in case of confrontation; Plus, Orihara Izaya is really the asshole of the series but the asshole you love to hate, which is a great deal in my book, mainly because of his rivalry with Shizuo. Now, the last 3 main characters (Mikado Ryugamine – the new kid of the block, Masaomi Kida – the best friend and mostly a douchebag at some parts, Anri Sonohara – the bespectacled quiet timid girl who befriends the two boys) were not that bad in characterization as they are mainly the observers and they developed partially but compared to the others, they’re kind of bland and worst of all, half way through the series, the show mainly focuses of them. Now, I come to say that their part involving the Dollars, Masaomi’s deal with the Blue Squares and Saki being in the hospital, and the possession of Saika, are not boring. I was invested in those plotlines, too, but the others never had a resolution solved and leaves me wanting more of that or at least a second season, although this series’ strongest point is that it had more episodes and needed more.


As for the animation, Brains’ Base made some bad-ass animation for the first 12 episodes, but when it gets to the second half, the animation has beginning to lag at some of the movements, the fights, the character animation and the designs. I guess budget problems got the best of them (hopefully not Gonzo levels) but it was a decent effort. The score overall has a major Baccano influence written all over but the opening and ending themes are where it shined, mainly the ending themes more than the openings. However "Uragiri no Yūyake" (裏切りの夕焼け; Betrayal of the Sunset) by Theatre Brook, I find more listenable than the second opening "Complication" (コンプリケイション) by ROOKiEZ is PUNK'D. As for the ending themes "Trust Me" by Yūya Matsushita and "Butterfly" by ON/OFF are equally listenable but I lean towards the latter for being more into the series than the first being just a J-Pop single.


Now for the dub brought to you by the wonderful Bang Zoom Entertainment studios and it was the first dubbed anime to be licensed by Aniplex of America and they don’t do much dubs due to business reasons, which I can respect, but glad this was dubbed however, there were some flaws I licensed in there but for the good points, there were great performances from Steven Blum, Crispin Freeman, Patrick Seitz, Yuri Lowenthal, Johnny Yong Bosch but the standout of the dub has got to be Kari Wahlgren as Celty. Some of the mid-weaker performances from Darrel Guillbeau and Bryce Papenbrook were noticeable, especially from the former, and Michelle Ruff was really off in her performance as Anri, which I’m sorry to say because she is a great VA but the worst of all is when they did a cameo from that other series that I mention (and I won’t spoil for those who haven’t seen it) and the voices are really off and that cameo was really unnecessary to do.


FINAL VERDICT: I really wish when Adult Swim aired this, I’m would’ve watched this sooner because I had some thoughts about it being boring and dull but as it turns out, to me, this is better than Baccano! By all means, this is an excellent anime for most of the first half and some of the second. In the end, it leaves you wanting to explore more into these characters like what any form of media should. Could it have been more interesting if that stuck with more of the better characters? Yes, but it didn’t stop me from loving this show.

Let's begin by saying that Durarara has all the makings of an outstanding anime; the characters are involving and deep to some extent, the build-up of the story to the conclusion is engaging and enticing, and it really makes you want to watch the next episode as soon as possible.
That being said, where the anime falls apart is its inability to pull all this together and reach an acceptable catharsis at the end.  As I said the story is engaging and it makes you want to keep watching.  The build-up heading to the end is outstanding and you really begin to care aboutwhere the characters are going to end up, but this only makes the flimsy conclusion all the more disappointing.


From a more technical perspective, the story is good, a little bit average, but good.  It's engaging and if not for the ending would be very good.  There's nothing to really say about the art, it's pretty good and doesn't take away from the experience.  The same could pretty much be said about the sound also.  The characters as previously stated are good and make you care about them, but the score for enjoyment takes a hit because of the way they end the story.


Bottom line though, it's not a terrible anime all things considered the story leading up to the end is actually a little above average.  On the other side of things the ending is so poor that the anime winds up somewhere just below average.  If you want to know whether to watch this anime, I'd say don't go out of your way to watch it, but if you've got some extra time and nothing to do go for it, the story is enjoyable enough.

Story 10/10
Durarara!! or DRRR!! is an anime with complex but interesting story. What starts out as something normal becomes something with intersecting plot lines and major plot twists that keep the viewer on edge the whole way through.
Art 8/10
The art of DRRR!! is great. It suits the tone of the series. Its realistic and pretty and makes watching this anime fun.
Sound 8/10
The soundtrack of this anime is one of the greatest I've ever heard with memorable Openings and music that fits the situation. 
Character 9/10
DRRR!! is a character driven anime. It has a great and lovable cast that make the characters more appealing with interestingback stories. The main protagonist starts out as a boring character who slowly develops into one of the most interesting that i have seen in a long time.\n\n
Enjoyment 8/10\n\n
DRRR!! is one of the best anime that I have seen. With interesting characters and story this anime pulls you into an interesting world. Even though some episodes may seem slow they end up picking up pace. \n\n
Overall 9/10\n\n

Well, this anime was probably the most boring anime I have ever watched. That makes me upset because I can clearly see the amount of love and effort that went into all aspects of it, but I didn't feel any emotional investment to continue watching.
Story: There was a story? Throughout these 7 episodes that I have watched I was hoping for at least a little action. Something to me make me care about the characters, and something to look forward to in the next episode. Alas, it never came. Suspense, action, romance, excitement; all of these are things missing in the anime (as far asI have watched it). It shouldn't take a third of a season to get all of the characters introduced. 4/10.


Art: The art was really nice. I enjoyed the animations, facial expressions, city landscape, etc.. No complaints here; it is a solid 10/10. 


Sound: Sound was cool. Characters had great voices fitting their personalities. Music was ok, but nothing to write home about.  8/10.


Character: The characters are pretty bad-ass. However, this series suffers from too much character introduction, and very little character development. This is partially due to the fact that in the 7 episodes that I watched, not a single major event occurred. There is a lot of room for character development but I am too uninvested to find out if there will ever be any. 7/10


Enjoyment: I was thoroughly bored the entire time. Even crappy low budget anime never had this sort of effect on me. Total snooze-fest, unless you enjoy mindless banter. Simple ideas and concepts were drawn out to make them seem more "deep" and philosophical. In fact, the repetitive humdrum musings of my brain were far more exciting than the dialogue in this anime and took precedence for my attention span. In other words, it was so boring that I had to force myself to pay attention. Did I mention it was boring? 2/10.


Overall: Good characters, no real plot, waste of time. 5/10.

Durarara!! is an interesting anime. It's an anime that is one of it's kind, besides Baccano!. With an odd fish that is swimming in a sea of moe and eechi, how does Durarara!! hold up?
Story:
The storytelling in Durarara, or DRRR, is very interesting. Rather than having a big overarching plot told in each episode, it focuses on the story and development of one specific character. And some scenes in one episode could happen in another episode and affect the story of that episode. It's a very unique way of telling the story and I really enjoy it. Some people say that the story-telling in the2nd half didn't match the first half's standards, but the only bad thing about the 2nd half was the plot twist involving the character Anri. If that wasn't there, the story would probably get a 10. 8/10


Art:

Drrr was produced by Brains Base, who haven't done much besides this, Baccano, and Spice and Wolf II. The art is very good, every frame is detailed, the animation is fluid, and the fight scenes are very entertaining to watch. I think I even saw some gradient lighting in the scenes where they were in warehouses, which I love. However, the budget seemed to drop as the series went on. There's nothing very noticeable, but it still could have been better. 8/10


Sound:

The sound for Drrr is very catchy. The two theme songs are magnificent, but only the fist ending managed to catch my attention. The music that was playing during the scenes in the show were great, but only one of them managed to get in my head. It's playing in my head as I'm writing this. None of the other songs managed to stick out, but they were still good nonetheless. 7/10


Character:

The characters in this anime are very interesting. There is no specific main character, similar to Baccano and Fate/Zero. All of the characters get an equal amount of development and all the characters get the same amount of screen time. It's a very interesting concept that should be in anime more often. One of my favorite characters was Izaya Orihara, who is pretty much the god of Ikebukuro, the city in which Drrr is set in. He knows everything and everyone, and gives cases to the Headless Rider, known as Celty, in order to stop crime under the radar of the police. He was one of my favorites because he managed to keep interesting throughout the entire show, always managed to pull a trick out of his sleeve, and was pretty much the nucleus of all the characters. By that I mean he managed to get everyone involved with everyone else. 9/10


Final verdict:

Durarara was an interesting tale that can not be easily described. Describe on thing, the other person asks more and more questions. Suddenly you say something about the ending and you ruin the show for that person. Durarara is an urban tale that will keep you, your eyes, and your attention on the screen at all times. Durarara gets an 8 out of 10

Durarara is an anime, with a name that makes no sense. Had it been "Dararara" I would have understood it due to it partially has something to do with the story. But it doesn't, and the name it has makes no sense with neither story nor characters. But don't let the name discourage you, the show is still absolutely amazing.
Story:
To begin with, there's not much story in here. The lead Ryugamine Mikado moves to Ikebukuro, Tokyo, to start at Raira High School, after being invited by his childhood friend Kida Masaomi. It is his first time outside of his hometown, and he suddenly meets manydifferent personalities in this new town. He is also told about color gangs, where the most discussed one is the mysterious and "colorless" is the one known as "Dollars" (or Darazu as they say in japanese). There is also a local legend known as the Black Bike, or the Headless Rider, which is where the fantasy aspects kick in.

Several times the presentation of the story changes, in one episode you follow Mikado and his friends talking about different things (like love, and color gangs), or them even witnessing a street fight (and a completely one-sided one, might I add). And then in the next episode you follow a completely different person, who experiences completely unrelated things. This brings me to the point that everything in this show is based off the characters, the story telling is put in the mind of several different people, and that is actually one of its charming points.

Though the story is almost entirely character introduction for the first half, pretty much everything changes once you get to know them, and the actual story develops. Basically, it's great.


Characters:

As mentioned, there are many different personalities in this Ikebukuro. From high schoolers to black market doctors, Durarara features many different characters, who are very well developed. The story is told from the perspective of several charcters, many of which who never even meet, and by the end you will feel that you know them very well.

Ryugamine Mikado is a timid, proper, kinda shy boy, and he isinterested in the abnormal. His best friend Kida Masaomi is a joker, he jokes about lots of things, and he doesn't act that serious until near the ending. He also likes hitting on girls. This group of three friends ends with Sonohara Anri, formal, quiet, and enjoys the normal relationship she has with her new friends.

Next we have Orihara Izaya, an information dealer who several times exclaims that he loves people, he also organizes several situations only to see how the people in them resolve these matters. He has a rival, Heiwajima Shizuo, he is the strongest person in Ikebukuro, he hates violence, but he constantly uses his almost superhuman strength to beat up people who annoy him with a street sign or a vending machine.

Next, Kishitani Shinra is a black market doctor, who is at several occasions called both perverted and weird. He lives with Celty Sturlson, aka the headless rider.

Durarara's characters are all funny, memorable, and loveable, and many of them also have something they want to hide from others. They are different, and it is likely that one of them will become one of your favourites.


Design:

The animation style of Durarara is one I haven't seen before. The characters are expressful and well drawn, but the surprising part of this anime is the coloring. Colors are a pretty large part of the story, due to the concept of the color gangs. Many characters will be seen with different colors on them, many where yellow scarves since they are members of "The Yellow Scarves", but the most noticeable one is the colorlessness of the Dollars. Most of the people in the world of Durarara are grey, or colorless. The important people all feature colors, but all the unimportant people are completely grey. This fits really well, because it not only shows a very creative distinction between important and not, but it also fits along with all the talk about the Dollars, and being colorless, also it is said that the Dollars have grown in numbers increadibly, and it shows that it is very likely that these people are in fact members.

The design isn't completely perfect though, yes the characters are well drawn, but not perfect. At times the movement looks simply unnatural (in a bad way), and the characters faces don't really look that good, especially the noses. Other than that it is pretty perfect.


Sound:

Another one of Durarara's strong points. The voices of the many voice actors all fit perfectly to their characters, and the acting is also performed commendably. This is one of the few times you will notice e saying, that all the voice actors improved the enjoyment, since all of them gave their characters more personality, and changing even one of them might have caused the series to suffer.

The great voices are also backed up by the great back ground music, the music style is good, and the songs are also good and memorable. Aside from the first outro, I actually enjoyed all the music Durarara had to offer, and that doesn't happen that often.


Theme:

The different themes of Durarara are, friendship, love, trust, humor, and gang wars, even though there is little to no action in here. Throw in a couple of fantasy aspects, and you're left with an amazing package. There is something in here for pretty much everyone, and it is likely that most of the people who see this, will fall in love with one of these aspects, and you can't really blame them.


Enjoyment:

My enjoyment of this show should be pretty obvious by now: I loved it. Durarara is easily one of my favorite animes, if not even favorite shows all together. I enjoyed every one of the 24 episodes, and I will remember this for a long time. The rewatch value is also extremely high, and though it doesn't exactly get better every time, it also doesn't at all get any worse.

This package contains loveable characters, a great story, enjoyable music, and everything required to be called as good as perfect. There are almost no flaws, and they are not at all worth mentioning. There's never a boring period, where you wish that something new would happen, the pacing is simply amazing. Therefor I heavliy recommend watching this. With the great, and satisfying ending I don't know if there should be a sequel or not. I want one beacause I want to see the characters again, and I want to know what happened afterwards, but if it isn't as good as this, then it would be a major downer. Therefore; watch this show, I recommend it as much as I possibly can, it's just that good.


Story:		10

Characters:	10

Design:	         9

Sound:	        10

Theme:	        10

Enjoyment:	10

Overall:	        10

English is not my first language, so grammar nazis please spare me
What would happen if a dullahan, straight out of irish mythology landed in modern Tokyo(!) and tried to live a normal life(!!?) in its downtown district –Ikebukuro? One thing for sure Durarara!! definitely has an orginal story.
Art 8/10:
Art of the Durarara!! Is incredibly solid, the animation is fluid, the characters look great, even our headless heroine doesn’t seem out of place. Ikebukuro looks incredibly realistic, the crowds on the streets, the lights,  it really seems real, and that’s the artstyle Durarara!! Creators chose – characters look like normal people(that doesn’t mean they areboring, more like believable), no bright flashing colours during the fights. And I have to say, even thought one of the characters doesn’t have a head, another one has superhuman strength it seems very realistic, thanks to the artstyle


Sound 8/10:


Durarara!!’s openings and endings are very good – the first opening is truly a masterpiece, the first ending became a meme(but mostly due to animation). The second opening was solid, and 2nd ending has a great song. The OST was by comprasion quite medicore, the music repeated itself very often, and none of the tracks were truly memorable. The voice acting was great – especially Shizuo and Izaya. Its also worth noting that the Eng Dub of this anime is actually GREAT. I actually liked English Celty more than Japanese one, rest of the characters are either equal or only slightly worse than orginal. Trust me if you want to watch an eng dub, Durarara!! Is a great one to pick.


Characters 9/10:


This is definitely the strongest point of Durarara!! The cast of characters is HUGE – and that can be a downside for some people(it was for me).  Even the characters that might seem like boring clichés(the shy,weak,quiet male protagonist and his loud, outgoing, strong friend) have their own secrets. Because of the storytelling style of Durarara!!(more on that in story part), the “bad guys” have allot of screentime and are well developed with their own motivations, heck some people will no doubt disagree if I told them who I consider the villain in the story. Some of the more memorable/unique characters are:  Shizuo- the bodyguard that dresses like a bartender, has superhuman strength (throwing vending machines like a boss), who hates violence, but always ends up fighting, Izaya: the intelligent, but slightly crazy information broker who just loves watching peoples reaction to crazy situations( the famous cellphone jumping scene), loves pissing off Shizuo. And ofcourse Celty, a female dullahan that actually has quite sweet personality, and that’s just three characters of Durarara!!’s massive cast(albeit those 3 are definitely the most interesting ones)


Story 8/10


Only 8? Let me explain. While the story is incredibly orginal, and well.. good, it’s the storytelling and the massive cast that lowered the score from 9(for me). Durara!! Essentialy follows 4 or more character groups at the same time, eventually merging them really late in the series. I always personaly hated that kind of storytelling – there will always be 1-2 characters you care about/like much more than the others, which makes me stop paying attention to other character arcs, and just wishing I could watch my favourite characters again. This might be a plus for some people but it was a minus for me. This also affected the enjoyment score. The ending leaves allot of questions unanserwed ( but offers some closure) – there is definitely room for season two(which hasn’t been announced yet, WHY?)


Enjoyment 8/10:


I enjoyed watching Durarara!!. It didn’t have me hooked like the shows that I rated higher, but I enjoyed every single ep. I watched. While the storytelling style choice didn’t fit my preferences, I still liked the show quite a bit. The unique story and solid art,sound and animation made the experience of watching this anime really nice one.


Overall 8/10:


Durarara!! Is very solid and has an unique story, aswell as a huge character cast(everyone is bound to find at least a few characters they will like). It’s a show I can recommend to almost everybody, from yaoi fangirls to boys raised on watching Dragonball. I can see why some people will rate this show higher, it can definitely get a 9 if you like Durarara!!’s storytelling and shows that have allot of characters

All in all Durarara!!, as obscure as the name sounds, is actually one of the better animes to watch. At first I was turned off by how confusing and plot-less the story was, but after somehow managing to watch a third of it, everything really starts to kick into gear. Durarara!! is about many different people with many different lifestyles within the Tokyo district Ikebukuro, and surely enough the rich character development becomes the centerpiece of this anime's enjoyment as you unravel the truth each major character.
Story: 7
As I mentioned above, there story was largely plot-less in the first third. This is not to saythis makes it a terrible terrible anime, just that its something you have to kind of push through. Honestly, if you were to ask me, "so whats it about?" I wouldn't be able to answer without giving you an essay. In the simplest words, Durarara!! is about 7-8 people whos' fates become cleverly intertwined.


Art: 8

Clean lines and soft colors. Good balance of dark colors--much of the settings in this anime are in the evening and at night.


Sound: 9

I am very impressed with the music. Music is unique, fun, and memorable. That's all you can ask for.


Character: 9

As I mentioned above, the characters are what make this anime great. Just to name a few, we have a couple of high school kids (the main characters), a Russian sushi chef, a mysterious "headless rider", and an inhumanly strong bartender.  These characters not only make the district of Ikebukuro interesting, but make the anime exciting as well. Over the course of the anime, you get to unravel the pasts of each character, and take a trip into their struggles that shape them into who they are.


Enjoyment: 8

It's fun--plain and simple.


Overall: 8

Great anime with a lot of character depth. For those of you who've seen Baccano!, personally I don't think this anime is as good but you can definitely see Narita's unique writing style that makes the anime magically get really good by the end. Definitely worth a watch!
